texts.content_text1: Before you get to the lecture, let's worm up and have a guess:
texts.content_text100: Every child who experiences a stressful event develops trauma.
texts.content_text300: Not everyone exposed to a stressful event develops trauma; responses vary depending on multiple factors.
texts.content_text101: Trauma can affect memory formation and recall.
texts.content_text301: Early-childhood trauma may cause memory gaps, repression, or difficulty recalling details.
texts.content_text102: A child who cannot recall events in chronological order is probably lying.
texts.content_text302: Trauma can disrupt memory sequencing; fragmented recall is common in traumatic experiences.
texts.content_text103: Chronic trauma refers to repeated and prolonged exposure to stressful events.
texts.content_text303: Chronic trauma involves ongoing or repeated exposure over time.
texts.content_text104: Preventing re-traumatisation is part of a trauma-informed approach.
texts.content_text304: One of the “Four R’s” is resisting re-traumatization.
